raw_text:
Continental 'may run out of cash'
 
 Shares in Continental Airlines have tumbled after the firm warned it could run out of cash.
 
 In a filing to US regulators the airline warned of "inadequate liquidity" if it fails to reduce wage costs by $500m by the end of February. Continental also said that, if it did not make any cuts, it expects to lose "hundreds of millions of dollars" in 2005 in current market conditions. Failure to make cutbacks may also push it to reduce its fleet, the group said. Shares in the fifth biggest US carrier had fallen 6.87% on the news to $10.44 by 1830 GMT. "Without the reduction in wage and benefit costs and a reasonable prospect of future profitability, we believe that our ability to raise additional money through financings would be uncertain," Continental said in its filing to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
 
 Airlines have faced tough conditions in recent years, amid terrorism fears since the 11 September World Trade Centre attack in 2001. But despite passengers returning to the skies, record-high fuel costs and fare wars prompted by competition from low cost carriers have taken their toll. Houston-based Continental now has debt and pension payments of nearly $984m which it must pay off this year. The company has been working to streamline its operations - and has managed to save $1.1bn in costs without cutting jobs. Two weeks' ago the group also announced it would be able to shave a further $48m a year from its costs with changes to wage and benefits for most of its US-based management and clerical staff.
llama3.2:1b: Continental Airlines warned that it could run out of cash if it fails to reduce wage costs by $500m by the end of February, due to "inadequate liquidity" in current market conditions.
The airline expects to lose hundreds of millions of dollars in 2005 without making cuts and may need to reduce its fleet.
Shares fell 6.87% on news that Continental had fallen 1830 GMT from $10.44 by 1830 GMT

The airline has $984m in debt and pension payments this year, but has managed to save $1.1bn in costs without cutting jobs.

The company needs to reduce wages by $500 million by the end of February or face potential losses in 2005, which could lead to fleet reductions.

The airline expects hundreds of millions of dollars in current market conditions without making cuts.

Continental's stock price fell by 6.87% on the news at $10.44 per share by 18:30 GMT, with debt and pension payments of nearly $984 million due this year.
The company has been working to streamline its operations and save nearly $48 million a year without cutting jobs.

smollm:1.7b: The Continental Airlines' financial situation is precarious, as they are facing increased fuel costs, fare wars, and the threat of bankruptcy due to inadequate liquidity.
The airline has already warned that it may run out of cash if it fails to reduce its wage and benefit costs by $500m by the end of February.
If this prediction comes true, Continental will likely face a significant financial crisis, which could lead to job losses and further instability in the aviation industry.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Continental 'may run out of cash' shares in the airline industry have fallen after a warning about potential liquidity issues, which includes losing hundreds of millions in 2005 if wage cuts aren't made by February.
They also plan to reduce their fleet without making those cuts.
Their current debt and pension payments amount to nearly $984 million, which they must pay this year.
tinyllama:1.1b: Continental Airlines has warned that it may run out of cash, after the firm warned that it could face financial losses of hundreds of millions in current market conditions.
The fifth largest US airline had fallen by 6.87% in stock prices due to the news, as well as a downgrade in its credit rating.
The company said that without "inefficient liquidity" cuts, it would lose thousands of dollars per day and may have to reduce its fleet if not.
Continental Airlines' shares had fallen by 6.87% on the news to $10.44, despite the airline saying that it could raise additional funds through financials.
Despite the challenging circumstances, the company has been working hard to streamline operations and manage costs without cutting jobs.
Two weeks ago, it announced cost savings of $48m a year for its US-based management and clerical staff.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Continental Airlines, one of the largest airlines in the world, warned that it could run out of cash if it does not make significant cuts by February.
The company stated that "inadequate liquidity" is expected if it fails to reduce wage costs by $500 million by the end of February.

Continental's warning comes amidst concerns over the airline industry's financial situation and its ability to recover from the aftermath of the September 11 terrorist attacks, which disrupted air travel around the world.
The company has faced intense competition from low-cost carriers and is working to reduce costs without cutting jobs or reducing its fleet.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Continental Airlines, the fifth largest U.S. carrier, is at risk of cash shortages due to inadequate liquidity, as reported in a filing to the SEC.
The company warns that without reducing wage costs by $500 million by February or making other unspecified cuts, it may lose hundreds of millions in 2005 and potentially face fleet reductions.
Shares plummeted 6.87% following this announcement, trading at $10.44.

Continental's financial struggles stem from high debt, pension payments, and operational challenges amidst record-high fuel costs, competition from low-cost carriers, and post-9/11 travel uncertainties.

Despite these issues, the company has already saved $1.1 billion through cost cuts without job losses, and recently announced an additional $48 million in annual savings via wage and benefits modifications for U.S.-based management and clerical staff.
